citeinfo.othercit: Coates, P.S., Casazza, M.L., Brussee, B.E., Ricca, M.A., Gustafson, K.B., Overton, C.T., Sanchez-Chopitea, E., Kroger, T., Mauch, K., Niell, L., Howe, K., Gardner, S., Espinosa, S., and Delehanty, D.J. 2014, Spatially explicit modeling of greater sage-grouse (Centrocercus urophasianus) habitat in Nevada and northeastern California—A decision-support tool for management: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2014-1163, 83 p., http://dx.doi.org/10.3133/ofr20141163.

descript.abstract: This raster represents a continuous surface of sage-grouse habitat probability values for Nevada and California. These values are derived from modeling the resource selection function (RSF) for the region (see supplemental information for more details). Higher values indicate a higher probability of quality sage-grouse habitat.NOTE: This file does not include habitat for the Bi-State management area.Coates, P.S., Casazza, M.L., Brussee, B.E., Ricca, M.A., Gustafson, K.B., Overton, C.T., Sanchez-Chopitea, E., Kroger, T., Mauch, K., Niell, L., Howe, K., Gardner, S., Espinosa, S., and Delehanty, D.J. 2014, Spatially explicit modeling of greater sage-grouse (Centrocercus urophasianus) habitat in Nevada and northeastern California—A decision-support tool for management: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2014-1163, 83 p., http://dx.doi.org/10.3133/ofr20141163. ISSN 2331-1258 (online)
descript.purpose: The purpose of this data is to provide wildlife managers with an additional resource to aid in planning and management of Greater Sage-grouse populations.
descript.supplinf: The RSF was derived from a generalized linear mixed model (specified the binomial distribution) that contrasted data from multiple environmental factors at used sites (telemetry locations) and available sites (random locations). Predictor variables for the model represented vegetation communities at multiple spatial scales, water resources, habitat configuration, urbanization, roads, recreational indices, elevation, ruggedness indices, and slope. Vegetation data was derived from various mapping products, which included Southwest Regional GAP, SageStitch, Landfire, and Fire and Resource Assessment Program. The model was partitioned into 12 subregions which consisted of 35,883 telemetry locations using 1,612 adult sage-grouse over a 15-year period (1998 – 2013).An RSF was calculated for each subregion using generalized linear models to derive model-averaged parameter estimates for each covariate across a set of additive models. Subregions were then averaged together to produce an overall statewide RSF of which a relative probability of occurrence was calculated (0 to 1) for each pixel. Values were then extracted from independent telemetry point locations (not used in developing the RSF model) to determine habitat versus non-habitat. The cutoff values were based on the mean minus 0.5, 1.0, 1.5 and 2.0 standard deviations. For validation a separate dataset of telemetry points was used to evaluate model fit which resulted in an agreement of 93 – 97%.
